column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0227] Referring now to FIG. 9, a passive method similar in theory to the active method is hereinafter described.
#Text=That is, rather than applying a changing torque to the wheel, an operating input torque to the wheel may be used.
#Text=Thus, the operating input torque to the wheel is an unmodified wheel torque from those of the normal operating conditions in contrast to that described in the parent application U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=No. 6,356,188, which is incorporated by reference herein.
#Text=Consequently, the passive system described below can accommodate the type of normal operating wheel torque, from low or near zero, to negative (braking) or positive (accelerating).
#Text=[0228] In step 210, the various sensors in vehicle conditions are read.
#Text=The following process is performed for each of the wheels.
#Text=In step 220, the various inputs to the method are obtained and calculated.
#Text=The input torque may be measured by a separate sensor or is preferably determined using the engine torque.

#Text=The operating input torque to the wheel is a function of the engine speed, and the distribution of the engine torque to the wheels through a torque transferring system such as a differential and driveline.
#Text=Thus, the operating input torque may be determined without being modified.
#Text=In contrast to an active system, the active system must have and generate a change in torque.
#Text=Also, the slip ratio of each wheel is also determined.
#Text=The wheel slip ratio is determined by the difference of the wheel speed minus the velocity of the corner divided by the vehicle speed at the corner.
#Text=Thus, the wheel slip ratio is a unitless ratio.
#Text=The velocity at each corner of the vehicle may be determined from the wheel speed sensors described above or may be a function of the yaw rate to account for the turning of the vehicle.
#Text=Thus, the yawing of the vehicle and the speed at the vehicle may be used to determine the vehicle velocity at the corner of the vehicle.
#Text=[0229] In step 220, the wheel acceleration and the slip rate of the vehicle may also be determined.
#Text=The vehicle slip rate is the change in the slip ratio described above.
#Text=That is, the slip ratio derivative is used to determine the slip rate.
#Text=However, the velocity at each corner of the vehicle multiplied by the derivative of the slip ratio may also be used as the slip rate.
#Text=It has been found in practice that this method for determining the slip rate results in a cleaner signal, which is advantageous in signal processing.
#Text=[0230] In step 222, the magnitude and sign (or direction) of the input torque is determined.
#Text=In step 224, if a large magnitude of input torque is provided (not near zero) step 224 is executed.
#Text=Step 224 checks the wheel slip ratio.
#Text=The sign or relative direction of wheel slip ratio and the magnitude of the wheel slip ratio is compared to thresholds.
#Text=If the wheel slip ratio is greater than a predetermined magnitude and it has the same sign as the input torque, step 226 is executed.
#Text=[0231] In step 226, the wheel response is determined.
#Text=The wheel response may be determined using the wheel acceleration, the wheel slip rate, or both.
#Text=The wheel response and the wheels' slip ratio are compared to a threshold.
#Text=The threshold may be a function of the input torque.
#Text=The terms divergent and convergent are also used.
#Text=Divergent means that the values are trending away from zero, while convergent means the values are trending toward zero.
#Text=In step 226, if the wheel acceleration and slip rate are both divergent and above predetermined corresponding thresholds, step 228 is executed in which a possibly lifted counter is incremented.
#Text=If this condition holds for a number of cycles, step 230 generates a lifted wheel signal indicative that the wheel has lifted.
